data.system_type_notes: Indonesia is a unitary state governed by a civil law system, but permitting processes are distributed across multiple government levels.
data.permitting_model_notes: Permitting is shared across national (MEMR), provincial (DLH Bali), and municipal (Denpasar) authorities, with no single controlling node.
data.digital_maturity_notes: The OSS platform centralizes applications, but many core reviews (e.g. AMDAL) are still offline and discretionary.
data.coordination_style_notes: Steps are legally distinct and must often be completed in sequence; inter-agency coordination is manual and informal.
data.override_culture_notes: Override mechanisms exist (e.g. political intervention, deemed approval reform), but are not systematized or transparent.
data.symbolic_density_profile_notes: Permitting is shaped by formal rituals (public hearings), platform signals (OSS presence), and informal local consent (village councils).
data.feedback_structure_notes: Includes structured feedback via AMDAL and informal local influence, with no unified tracking system.
data.coherence_baseline_score_notes: Moderately coherent due to known process logic, but high vulnerability to delays from informal vetoes and multi-level discretion.
